audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 21, Lesson 1. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Books for Unit 20 and Unit 21.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 20 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Sacagawea.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Review Phonics Cards
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.

Multimodal mini-lesson. Related root words. Many words are related because they come from the same root. For example, the words "teacher" and "teaching" come from the same root word, "teach." Knowing the root word can help you read, spell, and pronounce words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "teach" and under it, show "teacher" and "teaching" with the "teach" underlined in both>

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following words: "reader" <pause> "reading." What root do these words come from? <pause> "read."

Listen as I read the following words: "hopeful" <pause> "hoping." These words share the root "hope." "Hope" is still the root word for "hoping" even though the final "e" is removed. This is because dropping the final "e" is needed before adding inflectional ending "ing" to "hope."
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "hope" and under it, show "hopeful" and "hoping">

audio.transcription: Look at the words "hoping" and "hopping." Though they look similar, knowing these words have different roots helps us pronounce and spell them correctly.
Practice finding the root in the following word pairs.
Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about related root words, let’s blend some words with related roots and other word parts and sounds we have learned. Listen as I sound out the first two words.

/rrrēēēd/, read. /rrrēēēdûûûrrr/, reader. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether’. Say the word nice and loud.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about a dinosaur named SUE. First, look at the picture. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. SUE <pause>, skeleton <pause>, exhibit <pause>, T. rex <pause>, museum. Look at the skeleton in the picture. What kind of dinosaur is this?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about a dinosaur named SUE. The word is displayed. Displayed means “presented for people to look at.”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, displayed>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and word, excavate>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “A Dinosaur Named SUE.”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words displayed and excavate>

audio.transcription: Do you have any wonderings or questions about a dinosaur named SUE? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 1 in your Unit 21 Student Book. The title of this story is "A Visit to the Past.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: A Visit to the Past. This story is about a boy who visits a museum and learns about how people lived 400 years ago. museums display artifacts, or real objects people used in the past.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this story: excavate. To excavate is to uncover something buried in the ground by digging and removing dirt. Scientists who dig in the right place might excavate dinosaur bones or a very old city. What else might people find when they excavate?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, excavate>

audio.transcription: Read the story. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find two related root words for the word visit.
What did the boy learn about life in Jamestown from the museum’s artifacts, or objects from the past? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Why do museums need archaeologists to excavate, or uncover artifacts in the ground? Why is it important to learn about the past?
Anyone can excavate and make a discovery of some kind. What might you fi nd if you dig in the ground where you live?
You can reread this story during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.

Write to Deepen Comprehension: Write one or two questions you have about the Jamestown settlers and how they lived. <pause> Share your ideas with a partner before you write. Look back at the story for ideas.

toc.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Delete Initial and Final Sound

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 21, Lesson 2. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 21.

Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 1 in your Unit 21 Student Book. Whisper read the story “A Visit to the Past.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.

slides.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Delete Initial and Final Sound

audio.transcription: Listen as I say the following word: cup
Say the word cup without the beginning sound /c/. What's the new word? <pause> up
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
Now let's delete the ending sound of a word. Listen as I say the following word: beach
Say the word beach without the ending sound /ch/. What's the new word? <pause> bee
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.

Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review related root words. Many words are related because they come from the same root. For example, the words "unkind" and "kindly" come from the same root word, "kind." Knowing the root word can help you read, spell, and pronounce words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the words "unkind" and "kindly" with the root "kind" underlined in both>

audio.transcription: What root do the words "runner" and "running" come from? <pause> "run."
Practice building words by adding the following word parts to the root word, "read."
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "read" and the word parts "re" "s" and "ing">

audio.transcription: Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about related root words, let’s blend some words with related roots and other word parts and sounds we have learned. Listen as I sound out the first two words.

/rrrēēēd/, read. /rrrēēēdûûûrrr/, reader. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether’. Say the word nice and loud.
Let's learn some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: across, become, complete, during, happened.>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word become. Say the word with me. Become. Which syllables do you hear in become? Let’s clap the syllables as we say the word slowly: be-come. Notice that this word is made up of two smaller words we know: be and come.
Spell the word with me: b-e-c-o-m-e. The word "become" does not follow the rules. We have to pay extra attention to it to remember its spelling.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: across, complete, during, happened.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about prehistoric bugs. First, look at these two pictures. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. prehistoric dragonfly <pause>, wings <pause>, arm <pause>, dragonfly <pause>, hand. Look at the prehistoric dragonfly and the dragonfly in the picture. What is different about them?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about prehistoric bugs. The word is collection. A collection is a group of similar items.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, collection>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and word, gigantic>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Prehistoric Bug Collection”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words collection and gigantic>

audio.transcription: Do you have any wonderings or questions about prehistoric bugs? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 2 in your Unit 21 Student Book. The title of this text is "Máximo and SUE.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Máximo and SUE. This text is a photo comic. It has panels and text boxes like a comic but uses photos and facts instead of illustrations and dialogue. Máximo and SUE are the names of the two dinosaurs featured in the comic.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this text: gigantic. Gigantic means “very large in size.” The Pacific Ocean is a gigantic body of water. What is something you would describe as gigantic? Why?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, gigantic>

audio.transcription: Read the text. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find two words with the root word joy.
Where are Máximo and SUE? How have Máximo’s feelings about being here changed? Find the sentences that answer the question.
How can you tell that Máximo is a gigantic, or extremely large, dinosaur? Why do you think he was named Máximo?
What else would you like to know about Máximo and SUE? How could you find more information about them?
You can reread this text during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: Write a list of three to five facts that you learned about Máximo and SUE. <pause> Draw a picture to accompany your list.

toc.section: Build Words with Phonemic Awareness Focus
toc.title: Blending Focus

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 21, Lesson 3. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 21.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 2 in your Unit 21 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Máximo and SUE” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Review Phonics Cards
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.

Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review related root words. Many words are related because they come from the same root. For example, the words "revisit" and "visitor" both come from the same root, "visit." Knowing the root word can help you read, spell, and pronounce words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the words "revisit" and "visitor" with the root "visit" underlined in both>

audio.transcription: What root do the words "dislike" and "likely" come from? <pause> "like."

Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about related root words, let’s blend some words with related roots and other word parts and sounds we have learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
Let's find and underline each related root word.
Now, let's put a box around all the words with prefixes re- and un-.

slides.section: Build Words with Phonemic Awareness Focus
slides.title: Blending Focus

audio.transcription: Blending Focus: Use your letter cards to build each word I say. Let's start by doing one together. Make the word play. <pause> Add the letters -ing -.to make a related word. What word did you make? Playing
Listen carefully as your teacher tells you the letter or letters to change to make the next word with your letter cards.

Let's build this set of words again. This time your teacher will not tell you which letters to change. Let's try one together: Make the word play <pause>. Now change play to playing. Which sound is different? Which letters will be different?

Build Words Booster: Let's do some more word building. Listen carefully as your teacher tells you which word to make with your letter cards. Your teacher will check your work. Think about each sound in the word you are making. Use letter cards to spell the word.
audio.notes: <visual: show the letter cards to build the words>

audio.transcription: Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 3 in your Unit 21 Student Book. Today we are going to read some cumulative sentences. These sentences contain words with the same root and other phonics skills we have learned. Let’s whisper read one sentence at a time. When you are done, we will chorally read them together.
Circle all the words with the same root. <pause> Turn to a partner and read the words. Your teacher will listen in.
Write a sentence using the word friendly. <pause> When you are finished, read your sentence to a partner.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word friendly>

audio.transcription: Write a sentence using each of these word pairs: unwrap/wrapping, write/writer.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word pairs unwrap/wrapping, write/writer>

toc.title: Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus
Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 21, Lesson 4. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 21.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 3 in your Unit 21 Student Book. Whisper read the cumulative sentences.
Many words are related because they have the same root. The words "speaking" and "speaker" share the root "speak."
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "speaking" and the word "speaker" next to each other with the root "speak" underlined in both>

audio.transcription: Knowing the root word can help us read and spell words.
Practice finding the root word in the following word pairs:
audio.notes: <visual: show the word pairs: growth/growing, likely/likable, payment/prepay>

audio.transcription: Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review related root words. Many words are related because they come from the same root. For example, the words "dishonest" and "honesty" both come from the same root, "honest." Knowing the root word can help you read, spell, and pronounce words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the words "dishonest" and "honesty" with the root "honest" underlined in both>

audio.transcription: Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Then, read each word as your teacher taps on it.
Select two words with the same related root. Write a sentence using both words.
Introduce High-Frequency Words. Let's learn some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: hundred, problem, toward, study, wind.>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word toward. Say the word with me. Toward. The word "toward" does not follow the rules. We have to pay extra attention to its two parts to remember the spelling. to-ward.
Spell the word with me: t-o-w-a-r-d.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: hundred, problem, study, wind.

slides.title: Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus

audio.transcription: Listen to each word your teacher says. Write the word. If you need help, tap the sounds or use your sound boxes and counters to break up the word sound by sound. Then think about the letter that stands for each sound.
Let's start with these two words. Write the words review and preview.
Now write the words painter and painting.

slides.title: Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus

audio.transcription: Spelling Booster: Let's write some more words. Listen to each word I say. Break apart the word sound by sound, then write the letter or spelling for each sound.
sleepy
sleepless
untrue
truly
useful
using

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 4 in your Unit 21 Student Book. The title of this text is "Clues from the Past." Point to each word as you read the title with me: Clues from the Past. This is a poem. The text is formatted in short lines in pairs instead of paragraphs. An archaeologist is someone who learns about the past by studying objects people left behind. Read the poem. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Find all the words in the poem with related root words and circle them. <pause> Chorally read the circled words.
Write the sentence I say. Listen carefully and focus on one word at a time.

The first sentence is: One hundred painters entered the painting contest. Say the sentence with me: One hundred painters entered the painting contest. Now write the sentence. Your teacher will help you segment, or break apart, each word and write a letter for each sound.
The second sentence is: A kind person shows kindness toward all. Say the sentence with me: A kind person shows kindness toward all. Now write the sentence. Your teacher will help you if you need it.
Let's read each sentence out loud. Check your work. Your teacher will write each sentence. Correct your spellings if necessary.
Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 21, Lesson 5. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 21.

Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 4 in your Unit 21 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Clues from the Past.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Review Phonics Cards
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.
Let's review related root words. Many words are related because they have the same root.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "cheering" and the word "cheerfully">

audio.transcription: The words "cheering" and "cheerfully" share the root "cheer." Knowing the root word can help us read, spell, and pronounce words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "cheering" and the word "cheerfully" next to each other with the root "cheer" underlined in both>

audio.transcription: Practice finding the root word in the following word pairs:
audio.notes: <visual: show the word pairs: enjoy/joyful, dishonest/honesty, raining/rainy>

audio.transcription: Look at these words. Let's read the words together:freshest, refresh, refreshed, refreshing, moving, remove, movement, mover, unhappy, happiness, happily, unhappily. Now look at these two categories. This is the word freshest. Read the word with me. <pause> Which category should I put freshest under? <pause> Yes, freshest goes in the fresh category because the word freshest contains the word fresh. With your partner, continue to sort the rest of the words.
audio.notes: <visual: show words freshest, refresh, refreshed, refreshing, moving, remove, movement, mover, unhappy, happiness, happily, unhappily.> <visual: show word freshest> <visual: show the sorting cards fresh, move, and happy in a pocket chart>

audio.transcription: What did you notice about the words in each group?
You may notice spelling changes of root words in many words. As we read, let's look for words with the root fresh, move, and happy.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about exploring the past through artifacts. First, look at these two pictures. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. artifacts <pause>, King Tut <pause>, gold <pause>, death mask <pause>, Rosetta Stone <pause>, hieroglyphs <pause>, stone. Look at the stone in the picture. What is on the stone?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about exploring the past through artifacts. The word is preserved. Preserved means “saved and kept in good condition.”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, preserved>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and word, purposes>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Exploring the Past through Artifacts”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words preserved and purposes>

audio.transcription: Do you have any wonderings or questions about exploring the past through artifacts? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 5 in your Unit 21 Student Book. The title of this text is "Dig This.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Dig This. You will read about how dinosaur bones become fossils. Fossils are the remains of plants and animals that lived millions of years ago.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this text: process. A process is a set of steps that leads to a result. Building a house is a process that involves many people and materials. What is something you do that is a process? Why is it important to follow the steps of a process in the correct order?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, process>

audio.transcription: Read the text. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find two words with the same root in the fourth paragraph.
What is the process, or series of actions, that leads to dinosaur bones becoming a fossil? Find sentences that answer this question.
How is erosion, the wearing away of earth, part of the process of uncovering dinosaur fossils?
How would you react to discovering a dinosaur’s bones? What would you do with them? Why?
You can reread this text during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.

Write to Deepen Comprehension: Draw pictures to show the process of how a dinosaur becomes a fossil. <pause Write a sentence to explain what is happening in each picture. <pause> Then you'll write a summary of the process.

toc.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Delete Final Sound in a Blend

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 21, Lesson 6. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 21.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 5 in your Unit 21 Student Book. Whisper read the text “Dig This." Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.

slides.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Delete Final Sound in a Blend

audio.transcription: Listen as I say the following word: blow
Say the word blow without /l/. What's the new word? <pause> bow
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
Now let's delete the ending sound of a word. Listen as I say the following word: past
Say the word past without /t/. What's the new word? <pause> pass
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.

Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review related root words. Many words are related because they come from the same root. For example, the words "orderly" and "preorder" both come from the same root, "order." Knowing the root word can help you read, spell, and pronounce words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the words "orderly" and "preorder" with the root "order" underlined in both>

audio.transcription: The suffix "ly" and the prefix "pre" were added to the root word order to make each word.

Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Say the sound for each letter or spelling as your teacher points to it. Blend the sounds to read the word. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
Let's review some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: across, become, complete, during, happened, hundred, problem, toward, study.>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word across. Say the word with me: "across"
Spell the word with me: a-c-r-o-s-s. The word "across" does not follow the rules. We have to pay extra attention to it to remember its spelling.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it. Then, use the word in a sentence.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: become, complete, during, happened, hundred, problem, toward, study.

Build Words Booster: Let's do some more word building. Listen carefully as your teacher tells you which word to make with your letter cards. Your teacher will check your work. Think about each sound in the word you are making. Use letter cards to spell the word.
audio.notes: <visual: show the letter cards to build the words>

audio.transcription: Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 6 in your Unit 21 Student Book. Today we are going to read some cumulative sentences. These sentences contain words with the same root word and other phonics skills we have learned. Let’s whisper read one sentence at a time. When you are done, we will chorally read them together.
Circle all the words with the same root word. <pause> Turn to a partner and read the words. Your teacher will listen in.
Write a sentence using the word unfriendly. <pause> When you are finished, read your sentence to a partner.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word unfriendly>

audio.transcription: Write a sentence using each of these word pairs: playing/playful, unsafe/safety.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word pairs playing/playful, unsafe/safety>

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 21, Lesson 7. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 21.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 6 in your Unit 21 Student Book. Whisper read the cumulative sentences. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Review Phonics Cards
Say the sound or sounds for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound or sounds for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Finally, find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.

Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review related root words. Many words are related because they come from the same root. For example, the words "thinking" and "rethink" both come from the same root, "think." Knowing the root word can help you read, spell, and pronounce words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the words "thinking" and "rethink" with the root "think" underlined in both>

audio.transcription: The inflectional ending "ing" and the prefix "re" were added to the root word "think" to make each word.
What root do the words "uncover" and "recovery" come from? <pause> "cover."

Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
Let's review some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: across, become, complete, during, happened, hundred, problem, toward, study, wind.>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word become. Say the word with me: "become"
Spell the word with me: b-e-c-o-m-e. The word "become" does not follow the rules. We have to pay extra attention to it to remember its spelling.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it. Then, use the word in a sentence.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: complete, during, happened, hundred, problem, toward, study, wind.

Let's do some more work with this unit's high-frequency words. Read: Look at the high-frequency words. Read each word along with me. across, <pause> become, <pause> complete, <pause> during, <pause> happened, <pause> hundred, <pause> problem, <pause> toward, <pause> study, <pause> wind.
audio.notes: <visual: show "across become, complete, during, happened, hundred, problem, toward, study, wind" as cards in pocket-chart pockets, add one blank pocket-row, show tray with only letters for the first word.> [intended for teacher to model the first word]

audio.transcription: Build: Now let's build a word together. Watch as your teacher spells the word.
Now use your letter cards to build all the words.
Write: Write each word. Then write a sentence using each word. For example, you can start a sentence with "I wish I had one hundred ______ ." Read your sentences to a partner when you are done.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence frame "I wish I had one hundred [blank]." Then show "across, become, complete, during, happened, hundred, problem, toward, study, wind" as cards in pocket-chart pockets underneath sentence frame>

audio.transcription: Now your teacher is going to make a word with letter cards. <pause> What is the word? <pause> Spell it together. <pause> Watch as your teacher scrambles the letters. Fix the spelling.
audio.notes: <visual: empty pocket rows with tray with letter cards for 2nd word>

audio.transcription: Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 7 in your Unit 21 Student Book. The title of this text is "Come Visit Us!" Point to the word as you read the title with me: Come Visit Us! This is a brochure for a natural history museum. A brochure gives information about a place and all the things visitors can see and do there.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: What do you notice or wonder about when viewing the brochure?
Write a list of two or three facts about an interesting place you have visited.

toc.section: Build Words with Phonemic Awareness Focus
toc.title: Blending Focus

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 21, Lesson 8. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 21.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 7 in your Unit 21 Student Book. Whisper read the text “Come Visit Us!” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Many words are related because they have the same root. The words "caring" and "careful" share the root "care."
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "caring" and "careful" next to each other>

audio.transcription: These words still share the root "care" even though the letter "e" doesn't appear in the word "caring." Knowing the root word can help us read and spell words.
Practice finding the root word in the following word pairs:
audio.notes: <visual: show the word pairs: heater/preheat, uncertain/certainly, countless/recount, easiest/easily>

audio.transcription: Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review related root words. Many words are related because they come from the same root. For example, the words "friendly" and "friendship" both come from the same root, "friend." Knowing the root word can help you read, spell, and pronounce words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the words "friendly" and "friendship" with the root "friend" underlined in both>

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "happy." Add the prefix "un" to the beginning of "happy." What is the new word? <pause> "unhappy."
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable card for prefix "un" across from the word "happy" and the word "unhappy" underneath them>

audio.transcription: Practice creating more related root words by adding the following suffixes to "happy."
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "happy" and the word parts: "ness" "est" "er" and "ly"

audio.transcription: Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
Let's find and underline all the root words.
Now, let's put a box around all the words ending in -ed.

slides.section: Build Words with Phonemic Awareness Focus
slides.title: Blending Focus

audio.transcription: Blending Focus: Use your letter cards to build each word I say. Let's start by doing one together. Make the word harm. <pause> Add the ending -ed to harm to make a related root word. What word did you make? Harmed
Listen carefully as your teacher tells you the letter or letters to change to make the next word with your letter cards.

Let's build this set of words again. This time your teacher will not tell you which letters to change. Let's try one together: Make the word harm <pause>. Now change harm to harmed. Which sound is different? Which letters will be different?

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about a time capsule. First, look at the picture. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. pulley <pause>, chain <pause>, time capsule <pause>, container. Look at the time capsule in the picture. What do you think the people in the picture are doing with it?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about the time capsule. The word is unfamiliar. Unfamiliar means “unknown or not recognized.”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, unfamiliar>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, retrieved>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Capturing a Moment in Time—For the Future.”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words unfamiliar and retrieved>

audio.transcription: Do you have any wonderings or questions about time capsules? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 8 in your Unit 21 Student Book. The title of this text is "How to Make a Time Capsule.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: How to Make a Time Capsule. You will read a set of directions for how to make a time capsule, or a container of carefully selected objects that will be opened on a future date.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this text: memories. Memories are things we remember about our past. Most people have memories of special events, such as a birthday party or a trip. What are some special memories you remember from the past? What makes them special to you?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, memories>

audio.transcription: Read the text. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find two words with the root word friend.
What is the first step in making a time capsule? What do you do next? Find the sentences that answer these questions.
How can we use a time capsule to preserve, or save, our favorite memories? Why might people want to preserve special memories for the future?
What items would you put in a time capsule? Explain your choices.
You can reread this text during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: Create a list of steps for creating something else to preserve special memories, such as a photo album or photo collage.

toc.title: Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 21, Lesson 9. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 21.

Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 8 in your Unit 21 Student Book. Whisper read the story “How to Make a Time Capsule.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Review Phonics Cards
Say the sound or sounds for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound or sounds for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Finally, find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.

Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review related root words. Many words are related because they come from the same root. For example, the words "cooking" and "uncooked" both come from the same root, "cook." Knowing the root word can help you read, spell, and pronounce words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the words "cooking" and "uncooked" with the root "cook" underlined in both>

audio.transcription: Blend Words: Let's blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Say the word nice and loud.
Select two words from the list. Write a sentence for each word.

slides.title: Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus

audio.transcription: Listen to each word your teacher says. Write the word. If you need help, tap the sounds or use your sound boxes and counters to break up the word sound by sound. Then think about the letter that stands for each sound.
Let's start with these two words. Write the word review.
Now write the word viewing.
Finally, write this sentence: One hundred runners are running in the race.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about egyptian pyramids and mummies. First, look at these two pictures. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. Egypt <pause>, pyramids <pause>, stone <pause>, desert <pause>, tomb <pause>, paintings <pause>, coffin. Look at the picture of the tomb. What do you see in the tomb?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about egyptian pyramids and mummies. The word is honor. Honor means “to treat with respect and admiration.”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, honor>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, wonder>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Egyptian Pyramids and Mummies.”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words honor and wonder>

audio.transcription: Do you have any wonderings or questions about egyptian pyramids and mummies? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 21 Student Book. The title of this story is "The History Lady.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: The History Lady. This is a story about a woman who shares stories about the past with a class of students.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this story: inspire. Inspire means “to give someone the idea to do something.” A singer can inspire someone to take singing lessons. Who is someone that might inspire you? Why?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, inspire>

audio.transcription: Read the story. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find a related root word to visiting that describes Mrs. Carver.
What kinds of stories did Mrs. Carver tell? Find the sentences that answer the question.
How did Mrs. Carver and her stories inspire the students?
What are your favorite kinds of stories? Who or what inspires the stories you write?
You can reread this story during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.

Write to Deepen Comprehension: Draw a picture to remember the important details in the story. <pause> Label the details, such as Mrs. Carver, students, classroom, and stories. <pause> Use the drawing to retell the story to a partner. Then, write your retelling.
Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 21, Lesson 10. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 21.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 21 Student Book. Whisper read the story “The History Lady." Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Listen as I say a word: may
Say the word may, but change the beginning sound. Change /m/, to /s/. What's the new word? <pause> say
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
Now let's change the ending sound of a word. Listen as I say a word: send
Say the word send, but change the ending sound. Change /d/, to /t/. What's the new word? <pause> sent
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
Now let's change the middle sound of a word. Listen as I say a word: man
Say the word man, but change the middle sound. Change /a/, to /ā/. What's the new word? <pause> main
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.

Let's review related root words. Many words are related because they have the same root. The words "washer" and "washing" share the root "wash." Knowing the root word can help us read, spell, and pronounce words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "washer" and the word "washing" next to each other with the root "wash" underlined in both>

audio.transcription: Look at the words "play" and "rest." Create related root words by adding prefixes, suffixes, and inflectional endings to each root word to form new words.
Let's make a word ladder. I will give you a clue for each word to write on the word ladder.
This word names what you do with scissors.
Add a prefix to cut to make a word that means “cut again.”
Replace the prefix in recut to make a word that means “not cut.”
Replace the prefix in uncut to make a word that means “cut ahead of time.”
Take away the prefix in precut and add an ending to make a word that means “chopping.”
Change the ending of cutting to name something that cuts.
Let's do some more work with this unit's high-frequency words. Look at the high-frequency words.
audio.notes: <visual: across, become, complete, during, happened, hundred, problem, toward, study wind>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher reads a high-frequency word from the list. Point to the word. Read the word. Spell the the word aloud.

Now build each high-frequency word using letter cards. Then work with a partner. Take turns scrambling the letters in the words. Rebuild each word. Watch as your teacher models scrambling and rebuilding the word "complete."
audio.notes: <visual: pocket chart with 3rd word spelled out with letter cards: complete>

audio.transcription: Now your teacher will ask you to read and write some words to check on your progress. Congratulations on all your hard work in Unit 21!
